title: Filastruder Electronics Faceplate
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a printable faceplate for the temperature regulator and two switches that make up the Filastruder v1 controls. It is designed to be screwed onto the base board.

Make sure to flip the model so that it is facedown in your printing program.  You want it to be sturdy, so use an appropriate infill (50% or more).  When it is finished, the temperature regulator and switches should slide/snap in.  If they don't, use a file to make the openings slightly wider.  
Once you have verified the fit, check your clearance with everything in place, and then screw the faceplate to the filastruder baseboard.  Due to the location of the screw holes, you have to mount the faceplate before you insert the switches, etc. & wire them up.  Depending on how much clearance you have, you may find it easier to pass the wires through the holes and wire everything up before you mount them to the faceplate.

description.text: Its a Klein Bottle!
Cuando se usan intermitentes integrados es necesario este espaciador para cubrir el hueco.
An exoskeleton hand for stroke victims with spastic or flaccid muscle tone trying to regain grasp motion or fine motor skills.

All parts printed on a MakerBot Replicator 2 or Ultimaker with PLA and NinjaFlex.

Printing instructions:
-2 Bolts printed long-side down (PLA).
-4 Bolt caps printed top-side down (PLA).
-5 Hooks printed on side; flat side down (PLA) .

Hand: Small: 6" from wrist to tip of middle finger. Large: 6.5" from wrist to tip of middle finger. Print patterned-side up (PLA).

Cuff: Small: ~2.6" diameter; Large: ~3". This is intended to be worn with padding. Print proximal side down (PLA).

Fingers: Measure width of pinky-index fingers at the middle joint. Add .04-.06" and choose from pinky/finger files. Measure distal joint of thumb. Add .01-.02 and choose from thumb files. Print slot-side down with NinjaFlex.

Assembly:
-Screw in hooks to cuff
-Attach Hand to Cuff using bolts and bolt caps
-Tie finger tips to string/fishing line. Thread through hand piece. Tie to springs so hand is open when springs are in relaxed position
-Add padding to cuff and hand piece
-Add velcro straps to cuff piece

Springs: Choose desired strength (5/16" diameter X 3/4" length pictured)

I'm a Design & Technology teacher with a new MakerBot and I'm trying to think of projects for my year 10 students. This is an idea that I had, students will carefully pull apart an old (or new) working  USB stick and they would design a new shell for it. This project will test their measuring and CAD skills.
Here is my first attempt - not very creative but I just wanted to make sure that it was possible. 
Feel free to put forward any other ideas for year 10 projects... they need to be reasonably simple and they need to be smallish prints because at the moment we only have 1 MakerBot and a class of 18 or so. They need to be Things that dont take forever to print.
This is made for an Imation USB stick which I believe are fairly common. You may need a dab of glue to hold the shell on to avoid pulling it off when you remove the USB drive from the computer.

I made this Z End Stop Mount to fit onto my Prusa i3. It is bolted onto the Z stepper motor in order to stop the mount twisting over time and changing the Z home position. I have uploaded it in 30mm and 40mm tall versions to suit your extruder set up. I am using the 40mm mount with a witbox extruder, and the 30mm mount with my E3D V6 lite and custom direct drive extruder.

This is a combination of the Hephestos End Stop Mount and a section of the Z stepper mount. They were combined and trimmed in blender.
I print them on their back with 0.14mm layer height using a 0.4mm Nozzle. 2 perimiters, 0.8mm top/bottom and 20% infill. all at 30mm/sec.

comments.text: Can we get some info on this print.  Resolution?  raft?  support?  print speed?  Thanks :)
comments.author: smitywa

comments.text:
Sure! I printed it in ABS with a nozzle 0.5 mm diameter. I didn't need raft, and only a little support on the top.

A simple charging stand for 40w Eleaf iStick E-cigarette box mod. Charge your iStick without leaking or needing to remove your atomizer! Designed with a generous clearance around the USB connection so that most micro USB plugs will fit. Also allows you to easily pick up or put your mod down wile vaping with the passthrough charging function without disconnecting the charger.

Updated Design to work with the new 40w iStick!
2 Sizes available (Regular & XL). Regular size is based off the previous 10/20/30w design with updated geometry to fit the 40w. The XL is about 5mm larger in all 3 directions, which makes it a bit more stable but will take longer to print. XL is shown above in red

For 10/20/30w iSticks, use this design(white one in photo): http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:731360

title: Motor clamps for 8mm booms and M2 bolts (DAEDALUS I.O)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Simple yet effective motor mounts, clamping on 8mm booms using four 16mm M2 bolts.

Can be used on any motor with standard 16 x 19 mm mounting pattern, using M2 mounting holes, like the first Cobra 2204 motors. Clamps the motor down on 8mm booms, only requiring 4 screws.

Note: a version for M3 screws is on its way as well.

Use high quality settings. I used 40 percent infill, which seems to be very durable. No need to go 100 percent.

Print 8 bottom pieces and 8 top pieces. The .STL files only contains one half. You simply mirror the same part and you get the corresponding other half.

After printing, bolt both pieces together and ream the 8mm hole using an 8mm drill bit. Also don't forget the 2mm screw holes.

author: tebancho1990

description.text:
I've been wanting to do a project like this for a while now, and I started trying out some things with it, but then I got distracted with work and everything and put it on hold. Then I saw Makerbot's Catch The Wind challenge the other day and decided it was time to go back and actually make something of this.

Basically it's designed to be a wind powered USB charger. It harnesses the power of the wind, and uses a small motor to turn it into electricity. For those who don't know, motors and generators are essentially the same devices. If you put electricity into a motor it will spin the shaft, if you spin the shaft of the motor yourself it will put out electricity. So this design uses the power of the wind to spin the shaft of a motor, and then I've designed it to allow the electricity to run to a USB port on the side of the box.

This was designed to fit two other specific pieces. I've put the link to where those two other pieces can be purchased in the instructions, but since it's a work in progress still, I might change the parts as I experiment with new ones, but I have still gotten it to work as is.

I have a portable battery charger, and when I leave this sitting next to my AC it charges it. I've learned that this won't be able to directly charge an iPhone. Iphones have a built in mechanism that prevents them from being charged like most other USB devices.

I've experimented with a few turbine designs, but from previous experience, I've found Savonius cups tend to work best at smaller sizes like this since they tend to require a smaller amount of wind to start spinning, and they'll only spin in one direction.

As I've said, it's still a work in progress, so I have some work to do. Things I'm thinking of doing include:

-A lid, which I'm working on right now, and will have done pretty soon.

  • Fits for more kinds of motors

  • Different boxes that can be attached to other things like a bike or maybe even a car since those will have a lot of wind resistance while they're moving.

  • Possibly a gear system since the output is a little lower than I'd like. This'll take some time though since I want to make sure I get a good ratio that doesn't make it too much harder to spin. I've also ordered a voltage regulator, so my hope is that I'll be able to incorporate that into the design and then easily regulate the output from there. I will of course update the design if that pans out.

I'm also planning on making a hand cranked and a solar powered version, but those will be separate things. The solar powered version will be an easy change, but the hand cranked version will require gears to get any meaningful power of it, so I'll have to do some more modifications to it first.

I am of course open to suggestions, especially when it comes to the electronics, there's a few parts I'm going to order that I want to experiment with too in order to see what works best. I didn't upload STEP files though since this is a contest entry. I definitely will once the contest is closed though so that people who know more about this than me can help improve it.

UPDATE:
So I uploaded a second turbine design. It's almost identical except the motor fit for it is tighter. I realized my printer bed was a little close, so the first layers were a bit messy, and that's why I needed the hole as big as it was. After spinning for a while though it would break off the little pieces and the turbine would spin on the shaft instead of spinning the shaft like it should. I'm keeping the old one up there too though, in case your printer is a little less precise. Turbine Savonius Cups is the newer tighter file.

UPDATE 2:
I've finished the lid.I was distracted playing around with some other projects and stuff, but I finally put it up. It's a friction fit and it should just slide in no problem. I made two though, one with two side fins to make it easier to pull off, and one without the side fins. I've also tried another USB port that I've been testing all day, and it works well so far, I'll link to it in the instructions.

WARNING:
My knowledge of electronics if amateur at best. If you leave this connected to a phone or something for too long it might melt, or explode, or turn into a Decepticon. I really don't know, so use it at your own risk. I've had a portable charger hooked up to it for a while now though, and so far it's been fine. The voltage this produces is pretty low, so I don't think it's dangerous, but just in case, I want to avoid liability.

Everything should print as is. I used a Makerbot Rep 2 for these, and I didn't need any supports or rafts. The top of the Savonius cups were a little stringy, but I just cleaned it up with some pliers and it was fine (I also printed it on a mini, and it was much less stringy). There's two savonius cup files. "Turbine Savonius Cups" is newer and the hole is a bit tighter, I kept the old one (Just called "Savonius Cups") up just in case your printer, like mine was, is a little messy and needs a slightly bigger hole. I do recommend using Turbine Savonius Cup instead though and just playing around to make the hole bigger if you have to (I didn't).

I used 5% infill (I would recommend more, but I was doing a lot of prototyping so I just did 5% for the sake of speed. It's still plenty sturdy though), and .2 layer height.

All of the fits should be fine, however the USB was a little loose. I had to make it that way so that it would fit in, so you'll need to use a little glue, some tape, or just hold in place with your fingers while you're plugging it in and out. The motor should fit perfectly, mine slid into place and stayed unless I applied a bit of force. Using a little bit of glue to hold it in place too wouldn't be the worst idea ever though either.

The wiring is simple. Just connect the wire from one end of the motor to one of the inputs on the USB chip. I know the first USB (with the green chip) has a small light that lights up if you blow on the turbine, so that's how you can tell if it's connected properly (The second one doesn't light up with this device, but it'll still charge). If it doesn't light up just switch the wires, since the polarity might be backwards. You can see how the wires should go in the picture above.

I've found it's easiest to connect all the wires before putting them into the box, then sliding the USB in through the motor hole before sliding the USB into its slot.

I've learned that this will not charge an iPhone though. USB plugs have 4 pins, 2 for power, and 2 for data. Most devices just need power to the 2 power pins in order to charge a device, but iPhones also need to detect 2 volts from the data pins otherwise it just gives you the "Accessory not supported" message. Running the two volts requires that you 1) are generating enough voltage, which this is not curruently; and 2) that you run another circuit and more carefully regulate the voltage going to it. So if you want to charge an iphone with this, you'll need to run the power to something else first. I use a battery which I will link to below.

As for the other pieces:

This is the motor I used as a generator:
http://goo.gl/tUzfqx

This is the USB port:
http://goo.gl/blXG0y

I've also used this USB plug with success. I like the first one better, but if you don't want to get it as an add-on item you can use this one instead.
http://goo.gl/0gcBcD

This is the battery I've been using which I then use to charge my iphone:
https://goo.gl/8yCkEZ

The first USB port is an add-on item with a purchase of $25 or more, so now's a great time to buy that extra spool of filament you need if you want that. Really any USB port should work so long as the chip fits inside the box. I'm waiting for more that I've ordered to arrive to try out though too, so I'll let you know for sure. These were just parts I had extras of, but I'm sure there are better ones, so I'll keep experimenting, and I am open to suggestions.

That would be a cool addition, im not a circuitry talent myself but I would think it would like like this:
If LED lights are connected in series, the total amperage should be a constant and the voltage should be higher for every LED added. Sooo if you choose the LED's in such a way (or add resistors in a way I can't think of right now) that you need the max voltage output from the motor to power all say 5 LED's, then if the motor starts giving less then max voltage there won't be enough power for all LED's and since they are in series I think they will start dying out one by one.

comments.text: It might be worth trying Adafruit's MintyBoost in place of the USB power controller you currently use. comments.text: This is very cool, but I have some questions:
comments.author: frankvdh

comments.text: So the reason I chose that particular USB port at first is because it is supposed to automatically regulate the voltage to 5 volts if you input between 2.5 and 6 volts. Since the motor is a 6 volt motor I figured that would make the circuit as simple as possible, however when I put a multi-meter to the motor I was definitely getting less than 2.5 volts out of it, so to be entirely honest, I don't know what exactly is coming out quite yet. The Voltage regulator I bought, which is coming tomorrow, has an LED display which will clearly indicate what is coming in and what is going out, so that will give me a much better idea of what voltage is coming in and going out.
comments.author: frankvdh

comments.text: Hi Anthony, cool concept! It's been a little while and I'm wondering if you ever got back to this project. In particular I'm wondering if there is an alternative motor that might work better. I do think that the size of this unit is a big limiting factor but I'm printing it as is to try to prove the concept for myself before scaling up. My printer supports 10x8x8 prints there is some room to grow.
comments.author: TheSoup

comments.text: Hey, to be honest I haven't done a ton of actual work on this project lately. I've been taking a few circuitry classes, so I wanted to hold off on this until I learned a little more. As it is, I was able to get between 1 and 2 volts at the highest speed. directly out of the motor. I've tried using higher RPM motors before, but they tend to generate less power per spin. What I really need to do is work out some kind of belt or gear system to get a higher RPM out of the generator. It's a 6V motor, so hypothetically it could get to around 6 volts if I could get the RPM high enough, but since the USB plugs I used were designed to step up the voltage, it only needs like half of that. I have a couple of ideas as to how I could do this, mainly I want to try using ball bearings to minimize the friction between the moving parts. I also want to find a good battery I could attach to it, and a switch, so that you could just leave it out and have a battery fully charged.

title: Motor mount clamps for 8mm booms
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Beefy motor mount for motors with standard 16x19mm mounting pattern to mount to 8mm booms.

Designed for DAEDALUS I.O, but this simple design should be suited for a multitude of other builds as well. Experiment with those 8mm booms and look at my other 'things' as well!

Print 8 pieces in total. 4 standard ones, like in the .STL, and 4 mirrored ones.

After printing, bolt them together and use an 8mm drill bit to clear the 8mm hole. That makes it fit very snuggly over an 8mm boom.

title: Case for Sainsmart Huhushop Mega328 Transistor Diode Resistor Capacitor Inductor Tester

description.text:
This is a case for the Sainsmart Huhushop Mega328 Tester/Meter.

This case also contains a battery compartment and sliding panel for access to change the battery.

The tester itself will automatically determine the component attached to it and give specs. Will test Transistors, Diodes, Capacitors, Resistors and Inductors. Actually a pretty good tester.

The case does not expose the printed circuit pads for testing large transistors, but the connections are there on the ZIF socket so you can easily use wires or clip leads.
Print this items as attached. You will need to drill 3 holes for the board and use 4-40 screws. I used regular screws, but nylon would work too.

A fairly simple and very compact 220mm size quadcopter design. It includes a rubber spacer isolated flight controller platform.

Note: the frame in the pictures is a slightly older version of the model.

I printed the top and bottom in ABS with 75% infill.
I used 37mm aluminum standoffs between the top and bottom of the frame and 7mm rubber spacers for the flight controller platform.

Consists of seven files: the connectors, the bases, the arcs, the towers, and three different sizes of goal posts. The connectors are small rectangles that snap into the square bases. At the top of the base, there is a large space to snap in a tower. At the end of the four bases at the ends of each side, you snap in an arc to get the rounded look. On top of the arc, there are three staggered holes at an obtuse angle where you snap in the goal posts. All files come ready to print. I recommend super-glueing the pieces together so as to prevent any breakage. Print as many as you want to make either a short or a long field!

description.text: An awesome castle with a beautiful spire. Complete with residence, towers, and a drawbridge.

I made a beautifully designed medieval castle in 123D Autodesk Design.

To print this yourself, you should print all of the pieces out along with 5 houses from the house design, then glue them and the middle tower to the base of the castle. For the drawbridge, take some string and tie a knot after stringing it through the castle and drawbridge. If you pull the sting, you can raise the drawbridge and you can lower it by letting the string go. This castle is a fun item to show off your 3D printing skills.

Where to put your loose change instead of letting it fall to bottom of you bag. I've modified the jewel box design to include a groove on the top and bottom for a rubber band to hold the box closed.  The inclusion of a small indent on the bottom so you know which side is up!

To make this I did the following:
  • Imported STL into TinkerCad
  • Added groove and side marker and exported to STL
  • Error correction with Netfabb
  • G-Code with ReplicatorG
  • Printed on Makerbot Replicator 2
    • I would recommend you use ReplicatorG for this build. I had issues with Makerware.

author: LTMNO

description.text:
Inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9006, this is an attempt to create a parametric loc-line compatible 1/4" hose segment using OpenSCAD. For now I've only modeled a single segment, but plan to add accessories in the future (nozzles, mounting base, etc) Description of Files
  • The DWG contains my dimensioned reference design
  • The DXF contains a cross-section ready for lathing
  • "modular_hose_segment_from_dxf.scad" is a one-line OpenSCAD script to lathe the DXF into a solid (using rotate_extrude)
  • "modular_hose_segment.scad" is the main parametric script
  • "modular_hose_segment.stl" is a high-resolution STL export from the OpenSCAD script
    • Tweaking the script
    There are loads of variables in the script to play with, hopefully they are all fairly self explanatory. I suspect the two most useful (in terms of tweaking the design for printing) will be:
  • tolerance = controls the distance between the ball and socket surfaces
  • definition = this defines the number of facets for curved surfaces (sets the $fn parameter)
    • Feedback
    This is my first practical OpenSCAD design, so would welcome any feedback on how to refine either the object or my OpenSCAD coding style. Updates
    I've now merged this into a more comprehensive modular hose library - see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9457
I've not yet built my 3D printer, so I can't test the part.  If anyone is up for being a guinea pig, I'll happily modify the design based on your feedback.

comments.text: I forgot. From the derived from object get the nub and the cup size. See my comments on charlespax's version which applies to the original too. This would be a very good object when all details dialed in.
comments.author: bstott

comments.text: It currently does not print well and thus does not fit together. recessed cup larger or nub smaller. The skirt needs to be wider/taller. and they the cup is not deep enough to secure the nub.

I've actually merged this thing into a modular hose library - see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9457http://www.thingiverse.com/thi.... I will continue making updates to this library going forwards to refine the workability and increase the range of parts.

title: Eldar Warp Generator with hexagonal base
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I cleaned up the model by eliahu77 a bit and faciliated supportless printing by splitting it in several parts.

In addition I removed the asymmetrical arrangement by replacing the square base with a hexagonal one, simplified the center, changed the cable connection and added an optional crystal.

Update - Added:

  • Base with Saim Hann logo.
  • New complete files and versions without the center.
  • Assembled center piece

I'll (still) mark it as WIP till I made a print.

Print (split parts):
1x Base OR 1x Base Saim Hann
3x Stake Half V2 Left
3x Stake Half V2 Right
1x Center OR Center With Hole
2x Crystal Clamp Half

Glue:
Stake halfs
Stakes to base
Center to stakes
Crystal halfs

Attach the crystal to the base with a wire or the like.

Disclaimer:

This is fan art, published strictly for private and non-commercial use!
The Games Workshop PLC has sole ownership of the names and logos from the game Warhammer 40k and does not endorse, and is not affiliated with me in any official capacity whatsoever.

comments.text:
Yet another good take on this warp generator! I have to say though, having printed one of the blades of this remix flat, I prefer the vertical orientation of the original (or the full model you've created here). Has to do with my printer etc...
I've also found the original or vertical version doesn't need supports - anyone else tried this?
comments.author: eliahu77

comments.text:
Thanks for your comment.
The reason for me to split the model was to avoid the overhangs.
My printer (Ultimaker 2) does really good prints on flat pieces, but fails on overhangs.
Since I like glueing things together a lot more than filing and fixing them with Green Stuff, this is my way to go.
On the other hand i understand what you mean:
Since the sides of the stakes are not parallel, printing them flat leads to stripes on the surface.
I will add the stakes in one piece and the whole thing without the center.
comments.author: eliahu77

title: Vent or drain cap with integral screen

description.text:
A parametized OpenSCAD model of a vent or drain cap with an included screen on the end. Parameters include:
  • Throat (non-screened end) depth, height and opening
  • Mouth (screened end) depth, height and opening
  • Screen size and opening
    • Note that it has only been run with the mouth bigger than the throat. If you need it the opposite way, you may need to tweak the model. Note also that this thing takes quite a long time to render in OpenSCAD (about 30 minutes on an i5 under Win7) and to slice (about an hour and a half with Skeinforge on Ubuntu). As posted, it has a 5 inch mouth and a 3.5 inch throat. All output dimensions are in millimeters.

I visited my grandmother the other day. She had bought a chair for my daughter to use when we visit her. She stores the chair in the closet when we are not there. I noticed how difficult it was to keep the chair legs together.

I began to think about a solution and this is the result.
Printed with a Printrbot Play. Standard 0.20mm Resolution / 4 Shells / 15% infill.
It's a sand castle mold, it uses math, it can be used to make a sand castle geodesic dome! It just might work. We will add pictures when we get a chance to get to the beach.

Are FabLab class made this for the Thingiversity Math Challenge: Build A Castle.

Designed using TinkerCad. The half piece hex is for the base sand castings. And the little flat hexagons are for reinforcing the joints.

We will add pictures when we get a chance to print a few sets get to the beach to try them out.

Do I hear "Class Field Trip!"?

Sometimes I find myself getting lost in the declarative transform world of OpenScad... translate()
rotate()
scale()
rotate()
.
.
. Then I smacked my head and discovered 'multmatrix()' I know you, as I, have often wondered, 'what is the multmatrix?' This thing is the answer. Basically a bunch more matrix routines to make life in OpenScad easier. Really I'm releasing this particular bit of work because I want to write an expose on declarative vs imperative programming and how to mix the two for 3D design goodness. What you'll find in this package are functions such as:
vec4_mult_mat4(v,m)
mat4_mult_mat4(m1,m2)
mat4_transpose(m)
transform_scale(xyz)
etc. The devotees of OpenScad might find the gem known as 'ccerp' and begin to wonder what kind of crack I've been smokin on this father's day. But, that's for another post. The bottom line with this is, you can do your own fancy matrix transforms, and apply them wherever and whenever you like using the 'multmatrix()' module. Most people will scratch their heads in wonderment. Some might start bouncing down the halls with glee. The rest will just click on the next Colbert mash up.

1) Download the maths.scad
2) Use it to explore and learn about using matrices for graphics
3) Rejoice! If you have been playing with things like the hermite surfaces library, this one is not compatible with that one. Basically, the hermite looks like this: [[P0, M0], [P1, M1]] This thing changes the order to be: [P0, P1, M0, M1] So, be warned.

Which is cool except that recursion crashes after 300 iterations, so i have tried to run it in a loop and i am failing because openscad cannot change variables, i can only change a variable in iterations by calling it within a recursive function? i am confused?!? i have worked on it all day and have even posted a question here: http://forum.openscad.org/How-can-i-use-multimatrix-td13570.html

comments.text: ok, i can see the utility of using 4d matrix algebra to do scaling, rotating and translating, but what would you use a transposition for?
comments.author: MTO

comments.text: In the very simplest of cases, a transpose can take you from row major to column major form.  In my matrix functions, I'm assuming things are layed out in rows.  The 'multimatrix()' module assumes a column order, at least with respect to the translation.  A simple 'transpose' will take you from my row major order to the column major order OpenScad expects.

title: Kossel Delta Printer FSR Bed Holder

description.text:
NEWS: Initial release! See below for information

PART DETAILS

This is a glass bed holder with FSR sensor support for a delta style 3D printer. The goals I had in mind when finding a design I liked were:
-Wide support with 2x bolts for more stable support
-Longer platform to fit entire FSR pad on the support under the glass (no trimming required)
-Deeper platform groove to allow for thicker cork insulator under the glass without the glass being higher than the supporting wall
-Sliding position to allow for easy adjustment

This part is an OpenSCAD remake of the bed support on the OpenBeam Kossel Reprap. While I liked the reprap bed support I wanted it in OpenSCAD so I could modify it. The original source files for the Kossel Reprap can be found here: https://github.com/ttstam/OpenBeam_Kossel_Reprap

Let me know if you have any issues with the part and I will do my best to help. Feel free to remix to your hearts content!

Each bed support requires 2x M3 size bolts to secure to the printer frame. A third M3 bolt can be used in the middle hole for a bed clamp to hold the bed down if desired. The clamp piece shown is from the OpenBeam Kossel Reprap repository which can be found here: https://github.com/ttstam/OpenBeam_Kossel_Reprap

All parts were printed on a Lulzbot Taz 4

comments.text: Works wonderfully.  To prevent the FSR's from stress and damage, it's better to turn the FSR 90 degrees so the entire FSR and wire terminal are flat on the mount.

title: BAT Hat Ping Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I've been working on a "BAT Hat" for about a year now as a side project: Blind Assistance Technology. It's a hat that can provide distance feedback based on Ping sensors. Originaly I had the sensors hooked up to vibraing motors for a haptic feedback system, but the latest version plays audio. All through Arduino\Adafruit Wave Shield. Blog post here giving more info on the hat, file downloads, etc:
http://www.akeric.com/blog/?p=2114 I needed a way to mount the ping sensors to my hat. Originaly I'd just used some Shapelock to for some simple brackets, but they weren't adjustable, and looked like play-dough ;) Plus, I didn't have a Makerbot back then. The top part of the mount I derived from what UechiMike had developed (thing #19256), but the bottom was modeled custom in Maya: It's designed to slip around the brim of a hat, and you can drive a screw through the bottom to hold it in place. Another small nut\bolt hold the top\bottom brackets together.

Printed with Taulman 618 Nylon:
240 deg, hbp off.
.2mm layer height, 3 shells, 33% infill.
Think it took around 25 minutes to print.

title: Phantom 3 Pro Lens Cover and Gimbal Lock
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
A deluxe combination lens cap and gimbal lock. Built in guides grip the gimbal's heat fins and the lens cap holds the camera snugly in place. Easy on and off. Fits the Phantom 3 Pro camera. The design with small rails and groves means the camera can not move once it is in place. Decided not to embed the DJI logo, instead, used extra stickers to personalize the cover. I find this design is much easier to lock the camera for transport rather than the stock gimbal lock. The remove-before-flight keychain ribbon was obtained from sources like Amazon.

Updated: Version 2 simply has the keychain loop strengthened and moved over a little to the side. In addition the version with filter is for those owners with a filter, such as the Polar Pro filters. (The lens cap is slightly larger to accomodate the filter.) Thanks for all the likes !

Others say this design works just fine for the Phantom 3 Advanced as well.

Used PLA, 1.75 diameter filament, 2 shells, 50% infill, .20 height. Once printed, the lens cap should slide easily on/off without any force, use sandpaper on inside of lens cap if needed after printing. This cap and lock should slide on without force, but also not fall off either.

hole spacing motor 15mm - 20mm (for 16mm and 19mm)
i think you need 4-6mm long M3 screws
(2mm the thing and 2-4mm the motor)

hole spacing leg 19mm

First you put nuts into the holes, then you screw the motor and then you can mount it ;)

VL HR is front left and back right
VR HL is front right and back left

Sorry about my english!

Noch nicht selber getestet

Motor Tilt mit 10 Grad für 2204 Motoren

Lochabstände Motoren 15mm - 20mm (für 16mm und 19mm)
Ich denke man benötigt 4-6mm M2 Schrauben
(2mm Bauteil und 2-4mm Motor)

Lochabstände Armbefestigung 19mm (M3)
Bei einem 3mm Arm denke ich benötigt man 8mm M3 Schrauben
(3mm Arm, 2mm Bauteil, 2,4mm Mutter)
(Selbstsichernde Muttern werden zumindest in den unteren Löchern nicht passen da ich das Teil so dünn wie möglich halten wollte)

Als erstes steckt man M3 Muttern in die Löcher, dann schraubt man den Motor an und zuletzt verschraubt man es mit entsprechenden M3 Schrauben in den M3 Muttern.

VL HR Vorne Links und Hinten Rechts
VR HL Vorne Rechts und Hinten Links

If you have never played Forbidden Island by Gamewright Games, I cannot recommend it enough! It is relatively inexpensive, easy to set up,and easy and fun to play. The idea is that the players (2-4) are not playing against each other. You play against the board and cooperation is the only way to win. Take a look at it here: http://www.gamewright.com/gamewright/index.php?section=games&page=game&show=245

This is an interlocking plate that can be used to keep the 'island' of cards in order. As part of the game play you are constantly turning over the cards and after a while the neat island you set up at the beginning is anything but...

So to make things easier I created interlocking card holders. You will need 24 for the complete board. The way I designed it, all you have to do is press down on one side or the other to easily pick up and flip the cards. Assembles and disassembles quickly.

And no, I am not associated with Gamewright - except as a customer :)

Enjoy!

ANNNNNDDDDD I only just now realized I had misspelled 'Forbidden'. Sorry about that. Corrected now.
I've printed this in PLA and ABS. Should print easily enough, but you need 24 for a complete set.

description.text:
As per my GM's request, I actually fixed the mini to look more like my character sketch. Paladin-Caesar Cato II is no longer MIA, he miraculously survived, and last session the party got the following message.

"This is Paladin Cato II, Caesar of the Pax Neoroma. The crew of the Aetherunner unleased an Abomination to Our Lord and Savior in an attempt to assassinate me without leaving evidence: This Broadcast is a testament to my immanent death: Begin Ressurrective Cloning. Code . Not even their Abominations can save them from our Lord! diu Romae imperator renascentia!"

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/aghuwJ7qMZZ

A problem I was having with my Printrbot Play is that I would get into a print, things would be smooth sailing and then suddenly everything would stop and I'd get a serial error. Turns out the only thing supporting the USB cable is the jack itself. A little too much vibration or a slight bump can break the connection between print server/workstation and the Play.

It looks like Printrbot may have addressed this with a new USB cable with a fatter end that fills the cutout in the Play's sheetmetal side. I had both cables (not realizing they were different) and not wanting to take any more chances, I switched to the fat one and designed this gizmo.

The USB cable fits snuggly (so snuggly that you may need to shave a little bit extra away with an exacto knife to get your cable end into it.

I used a glue gun to stick this to my machine and it works great.

One tip: because of the snug fit, you'll want to put the cable end into the USB FIXER and then glue the fixer to your bot. Otherwise, the holes may not match up close enough to plug in your USB cable. Good luck, I think you'll find it helpful. When I get a chance I'll upload a version for the original skinnier plug end - though this one would probably work .

Happy trails!

This is a pre-filtering funnel for use with Sawyer Squeeze Water Filter pouches.
It has a standard water/soda bottle thread.
My intention is to screw this onto the Sawyer pouches to make them easier to fill (with the funnel part), and at the same time to keep leaves and twigs out (the filtering part).

This is an add on to Laird Popkin's 2 Liter Bottle Holder with Funnel and Cap. I added the grid on top, and an extra support ring where the cap and funnel meet.

I also intentionally decreased the $fn argument when rendering the cap so that it is less round, and thus hopefully easier to turn.

When printing this, I needed to slow my first layer print speed to 10mm/s. When it was faster, the little squares that got printed sometimes didn't stick properly.

title: Motor Tilt 10deg ZMR250 for 1806 Motors (Stronger Version)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Not Tested

Motor Tilt 10deg. for 1806 Motors (Stronger Version)

The difference with the version V1.2 :
1mm larger overall diameter
2mm instead of 1,5mm thickness in the range of fittings

hole spacing motor 12mm - 16mm
i think you need 5mm long M2 screws
(2mm the thing and 3mm the motor)

hole spacing leg 19mm
i think on 3mm legs you need 8mm long M3 screws
(3mm leg, 2mm the thing and 2,4mm the nut)
(Self-locking nuts are not fit at least in the lower holes as I wanted to keep the part as thin as possible)

First you put nuts into the holes, then you screw the motor and then you can mount it ;)

VL HR is front left and back right
VR HL is front right and back left

Sorry about my english!

Noch nicht selber getestet

Motor Tilt mit 10 Grad für 1806 Motoren (verstärkte Version)

Unterschiede zu der Version V1.2 :
1mm größerer Gesamtdurchmesser
2mm statt 1,5mm Materialstärke im Bereich der Verschraubungen

Lochabstände Motoren 12mm - 16mm
Ich denke man benötigt 5mm M2 Schrauben
(2mm Bauteil und 3mm Motor)

Lochabstände Arm befestigung 19mm (M3)
Bei einem 3mm Arm denke ich benötigt man 8mm M3 Schrauben
(3mm Arm, 2mm Bauteil, 2,4mm Mutter)
(Selbstsichernde Muttern werden zumindest in den unteren Löchern nicht passen da ich das Teil so dünn wie möglich halten wollte)

Als erstes steckt man M3 Muttern in die Löcher, dann schraubt man den Motor an und zuletzt verschraubt man es mit entsprechenden M3 Schrauben in den M3 Muttern.

VL HR Vorne Links und Hinten Rechts
VR HL Vorne Rechts und Hinten Links

(Es gibt rechte und linke wegen dem Winkel der Arme, wenn man das nicht berücksichtigen würde, dann würden die Motoren nicht nur nach vorn sondern auch nach außen bzw innen geneigt sein.)

author: RomeroMa

description.text:
Spectacles design loosely based on medieval depictions.

https://www.patreon.com/Marginalia

«“Oculi de vitro cum capsula!” he cried. “I had heard tell of them from a Brother Jordan I met in Pisa! He said it was less than twenty years since they had been invented. But I spoke with him more than twenty years ago.”
“I believe they were invented much earlier,” William said, “but they are difficult to make, and require highly expert master glaziers. They cost time and labor. Ten years ago a pair of these glasses ab oculis ad legendum were sold for six Bolognese crowns. I was given a pair of them by a great master, Salvinus of the Armati, more than ten years ago, and I have jealously preserved them all this time, as if they were—as they now are—a part of my very body.”
“I hope you will allow me to examine them one of these days; I would be happy to produce some similar ones,” Nicholas said, with emotion. “Of course,” William agreed, “but mind you, the thickness of the glass must vary according to the eye it is to serve, and you must test many of these lenses, trying them on the person until the
suitable thickness is found.”
“What a wonder!” Nicholas continued. “And yet many would speak of witchcraft and diabolical machination. …”»― Umberto Eco, The Name of the Rose

title: Mr. Twisty Dance:a vertical wind turbine or wind art

description.text: I made this while playing with openscad. It didn't need the twist, but I think it's much more beautiful this way. I didn't use a raft layer when I printed it so it came unglued about 2/3 of the way through.  I'm using it with a 7mm screw along with a generator, though I don't think it will provide very much power.  You can also hang on a string and use it as wind art.

comments.text: You said 'it don't need the twist' but it helps a lot.  If you fit this to a motor (generator) and suspend it by the back of the motor, it will spin with little wind but then, when the wind picks up it will lean with the wind and still spin due to the twist.  Great idea.  Thanks.

I needed to find a way to mount a webcam on my new reprap
(and to be used with my remote control/viewing software : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7187) and i had an old ps3 eye just begging to be used , so here is a relatively simple mounting system to secure the webcam onto a reprap's threaded rods!

The default settings are for M6 rods !!
Don't forget to adapt the mounting holes. Thing you will need:
From the ps3 eye reprap mount file:
  • print the bottom holder
  • optionally print the top cover (if your machine is precise, you should be able to snap fit the camera's base onto it without the need to secure it in place with the cover
    • From the rod clamp file:
  • print two clamp holders: this is a bit tricky, my failing extruder didn't help so it might be a non issue : the best solution with the current settings in the opencad file is to print without infill
  • mount the whole assembly in place with screws/nuts and bolts

SetTest3 is bigger and has 30/60/120/240 segments. The segment length varies from 1mm to 0.13 mm, with plenty of segments to give your printer heartburn!

description.text: Just some simple rings with a "wave" to them. These were to test the capabilities of my Replicator 2 with small objects, though of course my kids wanted to keep and wear the results.

Print directly on the build platform -- they are unlikely to stay put on painters tape and would just become part of a raft. I remove the smaller rings by placing a regular ring around it and tugging.  
At small sizes accuracy suffers and extraneous threads frequently happen, but I have successfully printed rings for my daughter down to 15mm. Printing mixed sizes (such as 20mm and 30mm) has resulted in the printer no longer extruding after the completing the smaller item.

This is a design to keep the nut from being loose inside the Z housing. I noticed I had a lot of slack with the nut inside the housing. The #2 stabilizer file has not been printed and tested yet. It simply puts the top of the switch flush with the top of the nut housing. Whereas with the original part and my original design, the entire setup rest on the Z switch.

If you print in ABS (recommended in order to smooth with acetone) scale it by 1%. The gap for the guide rod may still be a bit snug so you may have to sand it a little to reduce friction.

I just printed the newer version and it works much better. The hole for the nut was a little too loose for my liking so I used epoxy to seat it. In the picture the Black stabilizer is the original design and the red is the newer one. The stabilizers are almost completely flush with z stops, so a lot of the squeaking and misc noises have stopped due to better alignment.

I uploaded another model (Robo Stabilizer). It has a bottom for the nut so you wouldn't have to worry about the stabilizer moving along the nut itself. I haven't printed it yet but I'm sure it will work. I'll upload pictures once I have time to make it.

Semper Fi
megan

author: tpat591

title: Solidoodle 4 X-Axis Motor / Y Carriage Brace

description.text:
Solidoodle 4 X-Axis Motor / Y Carriage Brace

This is a brace to protect your X axis Motor / Y carriage from warping and melting due to misalignment or over taught belt. This will brace the motor, X motor mount, and help keep the X axis belt from misaligning.

I have included robust and basic versions.

Solidoodle4 .3mm resolution ABS
200/100 degrees
Takes about 1.5 hours or less to print at .3mm

  1. Heat up the warped X Carriage Mount by printing something out. I would say 30 minutes of active movement will warm up the mount enough for you to bend it back into place.
  2. While the X motor is still really really hot to the touch, drop the bed Z axis by 100mm to give you room to work.
  3. While the X motor is still really really hot to the touch, move the print assembly towards the door so that it is easy to access, Y axis +100mm. So that the X carriage is forward from the microcontroller cover.
  4. While the X motor is still really really hot to the touch, stuff two thick junk mail envelopes between the X motor and the chassis cover wall, in order to straigten and center the motor properly. If your belt is too tight, loosen the screw or temporarily remove.
  5. While the X motor is still really really hot to the touch, use some pliers to pinch the X motor carriage mount plastic back into shape. Hold for several minutes until the plastic cools and the motor is correcly oriented again. Do not pinch too tight or the plastic will break.
  6. Now that the motor and mount are correctly aligned again, install the Solidoodle 4 X-Axis Motor Carriage Brace.

comments.text: Mine melted like this too. Had to put hex stand offs on the left side to get the motor straight so that the belt had hope of tightening.
comments.author: FlyingMashedPotatoes

Above I have created some simple tools to help any person aspiring to begin or learn how to make sandcastles how the professionals do.

here a brief description of each of the items:

  1. the wall mold; this piece is meant to be used along side copies of its self in order to form hexagonal towers, straight walls, cubic towers, or anything else you may be able to create. it is simply 90 degree slate with spikes in the bottom for stability in sand and to slots for the compatable wall customizer (see below for description), one to activly use it in building and one to hold it in a safe location while using the 45 Degree function.

  2. Wall customizer; simply a piece that is allows the user to change the angle of the ends of the wall mold piece. To use simply slide it into the correct position facing forward on the wall mold piece, to stores simply flip it around and place it in the slot directly behind the front slot.

  3. Hand Scooper; this piece is basically a shovel in claw form, this allows the user to dig easily into the sand to get to the correct sand that is meant to be used when building sand castles

  4. Multi purpose carving tool; it is a multiple function tool that allows carving of the sandcastle, very small for percision details.

  5. round wall mold; very similar to the first item but is round and does not have interchangable wall angles

all wall molds are 6 inches in height
the multi purpose carving tool is 3 inches in height
this a ready to go sand castle building kit, enjoy.

Here is a link to a way to make a professional sandcastle http://socalsandcastles.com/uncategorized/building-the-perfect-professional-sand-castle/

and another
http://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2009/aug/01/how-to-build-perfect-sandcastle

title: High Flow Fan Shroud for Printrbot Simple Metal

description.text:
This fan shroud was designed to be:

  • Easy to print at .3mm.
  • Reliably and quickly rendered (no odd geometries)
  • Very open for air flow.
  • Aimed at the hot-end and the print.
  • Not damaged by heat or bad prints.

General Repetier settings:
Layer Height: .3mm
General print speed: 70mm/s
Retraction per move: 2mm
PLA Temperature: 190deg
Extrusion Multiplier: 1.15

Print out the shroud
Remove the 4 nuts from the bolts that hold the fan to the print arm
Place the shroud over the fan.
Oriented the hols so it points at the tip of the hot-end (down & front.)
Screw the bolts into the holes in the shroud, you should not need nuts.

comments.text: Made a huge difference on the performance of overhang, vs the previous recommended design from Printout (funnel type). Nice work. Thank you for sharing.

title: Wire Management for V-Slot Printers (MakerFarm i3v)

description.text:
Here are the parts I use to manage and hide the wires on my MakerFarm i3v printers.

  • The cable clips snap into the grooves of the V-Slot extrusions to hide wires inside.
  • The end strain relief mounts to the end of an extrusion with a 5mm screw and T-nut to provide a place to tie off wires.
  • The groove plate slides into the end of the extrusion to capture and hide smaller wires.

I use these parts to route and hide the X motor and X and Y endstop wires on my MakerFarm i3v printers. The X motor and endstop come into the X axis assembly from the right with a single cable bundle. The motor wires run the length of the extrusion, hidden under cable clips.

I also use the cable clips to route the wires under the extrusion to the Y endstop switch.

The snap-in clips fit pretty well when printed in ABS with a .4mm Hexagon, .2mm layers.

author: Allted

description.text:
King K. Rool Joins the lineup!

As many dedicated smash fans know, King K. Rool is at the very top op the fan made smash ballot and is most likely going to be the next ssb4 character (It was actually Bayonetta) . As a treat to those fans, I've created the King K. Rool amiibo based on his Smash 4 trophy.

There are 2 version: a version with no supports and a version with supports. I've also included my amiibo stand.

This is Recommended to be used with a Mii Fighter Amiibo Chip with a King K. Rool Costume.

This Project is a WIP and hasn't been printed before. I put it in Shapeways.com. a 3d-printing ordering program, to edit the model for printing success.

Please Check Out My Other Projects!
I made it using 3d builder by Microsoft and Tinkercad via tinkercad.com

comments.text: Awesome, and thanks for taking the time to upload! The only issue with the one without leg support was the cape wouldn't print connected. The other version, with the leg support, shows it's not manifold in Slic3r. Again, many thanks for taking the time to upload this, my son loves it! ~Todd
comments.author: ASLLEXICON

comments.text: I don't want King K.Rool in SSB4. I mean... what would his playstyle be? And he hasn't seen a game for ages. The would probably have to make a DK game for him again first
comments.author: Goombpaler

comments.text: In my personal opinion, I think that smash would put him back into the spotlight like Pit with probably a redesign and modern look. Sometimes I wonder why people are pushing for this but, I've realized that he's a important part in nintendo history by him being the main antagonist of the Donkey Kong Series. If Sakurai and the ssb4 team does him and his popularity grows I believe that he'll have a larger chance in getting a new game and getting in the spotlight. Thanks for discussing this topic as I wanted to show my full and revised opinion on it. I recommend that you check out the 3d model I have for King K. Rool. Thanks!

description.text: Truly amazing model. But to print it assembled you need a finely tuned printer. I have not. My first try actually worked, but the knob broke off, and the long bridges failed, looking messy. But I really want this one. My version craves a lot of assembling, 16 bolts, M3x12 or M3x10 and a good screwdriver. This version is smaller than the original. If you scale it 133% you should be able to use M4 bolts instead. I have not tried that.

comments.text:
I'm very new to this. But I was wondering if creating printable buttons with nipple in place of screws (which could be glued in place) could be created easily? It would be awesome to utilize all printed products for a finished product. I have not yet loaded a CAD program to create these type of items or I would offer. I am very open to suggestions on which CAD (free or very low costs please) to begin using. I don't know if the stress on the straight piece might be too much for a printed part or not in lieu of a screw, but would sure make for a cheaper and easier to put together end product. (Though I have to admit, as an engineer, I do like screws as it allows disassembly.)
Again, thanks for a great project!
comments.author: Mitch_N_OKC

comments.text: My best advice on software, is to use what I'm currently using: OnShape.
comments.author: Mitch_N_OKC

comments.text: Again, thank you for the praise. (It's not really my project) Yes, you could use plastic pegs but I don't think it would improve the model in any way. And yes, I really could appreciate the kick and satisfaction one get when creating a model made with 3d printing only. Especially when you don't need to assemble it in any way. I use 3d printing for making house models, and I have found out that I get the best overall results when I use 3d plastic only where the printer excels, only for the details (windows, chimneys, doors, railings, etc) and cardboard or kapa board for the large flat parts, walls and roofs. I use Sketchup for designing. It's free for personal use. It can import and export STL files. (You need a free addon for that). http://www.sketchup.com. Hmmm... You perhaps can make pegs out of small pieces of filament and a soldering iron, without the printer. Use the iron to melt the ends to form a head. Good luck. Tell us how it works out.
comments.author: Mitch_N_OKC

comments.text: Hi, Thanks again for your reply.  I realize your posted files are a remix of the all 1 piece printed object, but being very new with a new printer, I didn't think I would even attempt that design.  Yours seemed the best bet for success.  At this point I'm waiting on screws i purchased through ebay.  I'll look at sketchup and see if it suits my needs.  I was just thinking that with the likely success of this remix that the pegs might be a good balance between the durability and ease of assembly/build from resource standpoint.  I don't know the mechanical stress that might be placed on the pegs from say a 5lb load.  I just know this is a device I have needed several times and look forward to its use.  I'm having lots of fun so far!  I'll try to find a way to create a version with pegs and post pictures as soon as I get one assembled.  I have only printed the parts in PLA thus far.  I didn't see any reference as to which filament to use and I don't even know how well my (low cost) printer will do with the ABS.  Still, I'm having lots of fun and thank everyone on here for the desire to help each other with the postings.  Thank you for your advice and help!
comments.author: Stodatgard

comments.text: I use only PLA. They say that the smell of melting ABS is not very nice to have indoors. Also, PLA is more environment friendly, made from corn. 5lb, that's 2,3 kilograms? Sounds a lot to me. You are actually going to make something useful of this? To me, this is just a toy, a conversation piece. But I wish you the best of luck. I don't think the plastic threads can stand much wear and load. I would consider integrating a steel bolt or a threaded bar instead, with a wing nut and some washers. Or something. And put more material in the arms and axes, make everything sturdier. Depending on what you actually doing. You really need something like Sketchup for the redesign. Yes, this is great fun.
comments.author: Mitch_N_OKC

comments.author: Mitch_N_OKC

comments.text: Much depends on the tuning and settings of your printer. It's hard to get a snug fit. Try some glue.
comments.author: Mitch_N_OKC

comments.text:
It was not that it was not dialed in. Though this is only my 4th print on a new machine (my first machine). However, I reprinted it at 90% and it fits perfectly. Glue will now work perfectly. The original knob was from printing all parts at once. So I thought that since I had to reprint the screw (it broke loose from the bed and failed while printing all parts), that the individual separations were at a different scale then the multi part print - but no. I don't have a program beyond cura at the moment to measure the sizes, so I just guessed (I feel bad that I didn't actually measure and scale correctly) at 90% and it fit perfectly!
Great project!

title: Easy and Universal Fan Clip Mount For Acrylic (Or other) Frames Sunhokey 2015

description.text:
I couldn't find a simple one, so i made one! This little mount clips onto the top of a piece of 6.5mm (Approx) Acrylic or similar material and works a treat! Great for increasing airflow or making an ABS fume force field!

Print however you like, i used 20% infill at a 2mm layer height in PLA, worked a treat and it pretty strong.

ALSO included is a 90 Degrees version to allow you to tilt fans inwards, upwards for ventilation or downwards for above cooling! Its up to you!

Happy Printing!
100% infill is probably best for a strong hold, its small so don't worry.

But, if you really need the design, here ya go! '

The All in one design using the stock fan does work, just it degrades over time... :( I think only having one fan to cool the hotend and the nozzle resulted in the hotend heating up to much in the middle, making the printed cooler softer, then making it fall off in my case.

title: Printable Tripod Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
In response to the remake challenge, http://blog.thingiverse.com/2009/08/26/remake-challenge-iphone-tripod-mount/, a portable media tripod mount. The adapter will fit many different handheld devices, and is reconfigurable to have either the single or double support block on top and bottom. Smallest clamping size: 1.75in
Largest Clamping size: 3in.
Ideal fit: iphone The two clamping arms fit into each other to prevent lateral movement. The female attachment has a press fit for a 1/4-20 nut, acting as the tripod mount. To eliminate the lateral movement between the female and either clamp arm there is a modeled \"peg\" and complementing features; however, there is probably a better solution. Adding a low durometer material to the clamp fingers would make a nice grip without damaging the phone surface.

Hardware needed for assembly: 1x 10-24 thread wing nut (#98671A150 Mcmaster-Carr)
1x 10-24 thread 4in pan head bolt (#99117A510 Mcmaster-Carr)
1x 1/4-20 hex nut (#90498A029 Mcmaster-Carr) Enjoy!

description.text: Use "fancy 3d printable cord stopper" instead.  It is the same as this but with a provision for an additional circle spring and grippy teeth and is easily customizable.

There are some parameters in the SCAD file to adjust for various dimensions and also for the part clearance, etc.  The STL is the one I printed out (in ABS) and am using now.  I recommend only making the spring thickness equal to your extrusion width.  I tried it with multiple perimeters to increase the tension but the additional layers reduces the elasticity.  I may tweak it again with multiple, unconnected spring perimeters if I get inspired.  
I imagine that the springiness will not hold up well over time due to the nature of thermoplastics, so I may make another one that can be used with a standard compression spring, but I wanted to make one that was 100% 3d printable just for the challenge of it.
SPEICAL PIOCHE

My first drawing and personally designed print.

Fits the nexus 6 super tight (not tight enough to break the print) you can give it a good shake from the hinge and it's still fine and holds the phone.

What I really want to do is create different arms that come off the back/front (where I have the bolts) to serve different functions.
*eg. Arms with hooks to hang out of a car vent for gps/music function

The last two pictures in the gallery are of an older design which wound up being too wide. Now I use it as a camera hanger for my printer :P

Just wanted to get this out there to see if i can get some feedback from more experienced printers. (Boy, could I use it :P)

Drawn in Autocad
Printed in ABS
Light on supports
.3 height

I thought the look of the top of the hotend carriage looked pretty bad with the wires and bowden tube showing, so I made a cap! It reuses the nuts and bolts from the stock hotend carriage, and makes the machine look more professional. Made with Autodesk Inventor 2016.
Printed in abs with 15% infill. make sure your nuts are about the same size as the one measured or they may not fit and you'll have to scale up the model slightly to fit.

title: A vRoomba - Pull Back Motor Vacuum Robot

description.text:
I measured a simple "Pull Back" style motor that I found in a dollar-store toy, and recreated the "Cat on a Vacuum" meme that you see on YouTube videos with this toy.  
The design of the robotic sweeper was entirely by eyeball, and made just thick enough to hide the motor.  No specific brand of automatic carpet cleaning device is expressed or implied, of course.  Any resemblance to an actual trademarked product is just as coincidental as a company naming itself with a lowercase-i-capital-noun format (like Apple products) or naming itself after famous science fiction stories (like Asimov's books).  
For some reason, Slic3r 0.9.9 complains about it being non-manifold, but Blender cannot find any fault with the STL.  The slicing results are perfect.  I recommend the concentric top fill to complement the contours of the robot.

This uses a cheap "Pull Back" style motor I scavenged from a dollar store toy kit. I used mechanical pencil erasers as tires, and melt-insert some metal bushings for the front axle. (The melt-insert threaded bushings are optional, but McMaster-Carr part 94180A331 is a bag of 100. Great for 3D printed projects!) A more complete picture gallery with helpful tips is at http://imgur.com/a/eD9cW If your pull back motor differs, you will obviously need to adjust the STL design of the model. However, I hope this project inspires many people to run to their local discount/dollar/100yen store and look for new ways to mashup common toys with uncommon ideas.

This is a larger version of the 27-LED stubby flashlight except with 36 10mm-size LEDs. For now the bottom switch plate is designed for supporting four pushbutton switches (for activating four different 9-LED segments).

Both the LED and switch mounts are removable and are secured via a number of small screws.

You'll need to figure out how much voltage you'll be using and the appropriate resistor(s) for your LEDs.

UPDATE: I've included another bottom switchplate. This time it has openings for four rocker-style switches. Also I've found the holes are best suited for use with #6 sheet metal screws.
You'll need 36 10mm-size LEDs, battery and holder, and up to four pushbutton switches.

title: Four lobe 5.8 GHz circular polarized antenna template kit (Skew-planar)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Kit for "easily" building 4 lobe LHCP/RHCP 5.8GHz antennas for FPV.

Can be used both for VRx and VTx.
The template allows you to reproduce the antennas to create matching pairs for both VTx and VRx as well as creating spares that match your existing antennas.
How to use a similar template and build an antenna: https://youtu.be/8PKhqbBy2ls

Use the SPW58_Template.stl for best match with Circular Wireless SPW58 antennas.

Note: If you are just looking to save a few bucks on an antenna, this is probably not for you.

Print all items at 0.1 layer height, solid infill, ABS. Do not use PLA - it will melt when soldering. You can get away with printing the pingpong ball cutting tool with 15% infill.

To build an antenna you need:

Tools:

Needle nose pliers
Soldering station
Solder
Hot glue gun
Heat gun
Exacto knife
Cue tip
Isopropyl alcohol
Materials:

400mm 0.5mm copper wire (or 0.8mm MIG welding wire)
46.5 mm semi-rigid flexible RG402 0.141" RF coaxial cable
40mm ping-pong ball
SMA (or RP-SMA) Male Plug Solder For Semi-Rigid RG402 0.141" Cable RF Connector
25mm Ø6mm heat shrink
CA glue
How to:
1) Use the bending template to cut the wire (6 pieces) to length and bend the wire at 90 degree angles using a set of pliers.
2) Then bend the wire to fit the template.
3) Now twist the loap 45 degrees left or right to create a LHCP or RHCP antenna.
4) Assemble the Four lobe alignment wheel with with the six lobe alignment wheel center.
5) Place the 4 lobes in the alignment wheel and secure them with a dap of hot glue.
7) cut 3mm of the insulation of the RG402 wire at each end, exposing the inner core.
8) Remove the sFour lobe alignment wheel center and place one end of the RG402inside the 6 pegs of the lobes.
9) Cut the heat shrink into 3 pieces: 10mm/10mm/5mm
10) place the 5mm piece of heat shrink over the 4 pegs of the lobes and carefully heat the heat shrink with the heat gun WITHOUT melting the hot glue (or ABS) - The pegs and RG402 are now somewhat secured.
11) Solder the pegs to the RG402 once again careful not to melt the hot glue or ABS.
12) Remove the 5mm piece of heat shrink with an exacto knife
13) place on 10mm piece of heat shrink around the 4 pegs and the RG402 and gently heat with the heat gun to shrink it into place
14) align the lobes with the 3mm stump of core and carefully solder them in place.
15) Using the cue tip, dap some isopropyl alcohol onto the hot glue and remove the hot glue once the isopropyl alcohol has done its magic.
16) Remove the antenna from the alignment wheel.
17) Place a 10mm piece of heat shrink on the RG402 as close to the loops as possible - do not shrink it!
18) Place the Six lobe dome base on the antenna.
19) Solder the SMA peg onto the RG402 core
20) solder the SMA connector onto the RG402 cable
21) Push the 10mm piece of heat shrink over the SMA connector base and heat to shrink into place.
22) Glue the six lobe dome base to the base of the antenna (heat shrink) to secure it to the antenna.
23) Place a ping-pong ball between the two halves of the ping-pong ball cutting tool (The "seem" of the ball should go opposite the cutting direction for easiest cut).
24) use the exacto knife to gradually cut though the ball
25) Place one half of the ball onto the Four lobe dome base and secure it with CA.

comments.text: Why the shape of the lobes is different with 0.5 wire and 0.8 wire ??
comments.author: juanvivo

comments.text: I uploaded a remix of the alignment wheel.  I had to increase the center width to 8.95mm in order for the center alignment wheel fixture to fit.  Not sure why there is so much shrinkage of the material when printing in that area.   Six lobe has the same issue.  Center fixture when printed is only 7.36mm wide and the fixture that fits in the center is 8.24 and will not fit.  I had to use sketchup to modify the 4 lobe which is not very efficient to do.  Would it be possible for you to increase the 6 lobe center an additional  1mm?
comments.author: Ace01

comments.text: Can the 4 lobe be used for the VTX and  video receiver?  I was told to use a 3 lobe for the VTX and a 4 lobe for the video receiver.
comments.author: Ace01

comments.text: The same way that the Circular Wireless SPW58 or the Fatshark Spiro antennas (both four lobe) can be used both as receiver and transmitter antennas, so can these. Simple test: If it works for you - it works for you. As I see it, there is a slight production cost increase in the 4 lobe over the 3 lobe antennas. I am using 4 lobe or 6 lobe antennas on my VTx and 4 lobe (Circular Wireless SPW58) antennas on my receiver.
comments.author: Ace01

comments.text: I believe IB crazy calls the 4 lobe a mad mushroom.  I printed several of your 4 and 6 lobe molds and will be manufacturing a few of them for testing.  Only issue I am having with the 3D print of the parts is the lower part were you put the tail of the antenna in does not fit the mold fixture.  Will have to do some filling and sanding.  Thank you for designing these parts.
comments.author: Motorpixiegimbals

comments.text: Thank you for creating this
comments.author: Ace01

comments.text: Have any antenna made with this been tested?
comments.author: MiniMil

comments.text: Only real life testing. With two identical antennas made with the SPW58 template I get the same range I get with the store bought Circular Wireless SPW58 antennas. Since range is dependent on moisture in the air, obstacles, altitude, angle of the antennas in relation to each other at any given moment and the VTx and VRx it does not make sense for me to state 500m or 5km. I use the antennas for proximity FPV flying.

comments.text: I'm not so much worried about the range of the antenna, as much as I am if it is not quite right will it create dirty RF that will mess with fellow fpvers

author: camosniper00

description.text:
I designed this small car for my nephew's birthday. It is simple in design and assembly. Have fun!

NOTE: The wheels are very small, pay attention about choking or aspiration of these small parts!!

First, I printed the main body and the wheels separately with an orange PLA filament.

Then I added the wheels to the main body with hot glue.

Finally I decided to color the wheels with a dark pen, but you can print them with a black filament directly.

Have fun!

I've encased the m3d printer with acrylic glass. I bought it cut into rectangles of 150mm x 140mm (I've ordered them online for about 20€ in total - on hindsight, I should have ordered 5 because I damaged one when drilling. Making them square would have also been useful). I drilled 4 holes with 4 mm diameter each - I also created a fitter object that can be used to mark the holes.

There are 3 pieces of holders that are put on the bottom and one of the sides of the glass. The piece with the small spring is put on the other side. Once you've assembled everything, you can slide the glass on the open holes of the printer on each side. The spring pushes the glass slightly back and keeps the glass in place.

comments.text: Hey you mentioned you used 140x150mm acrylic. Which direction did you run the 150--vertically or horizontally?
comments.author: epiblitikos

comments.text: Hi Why need it?
comments.author: mp3lll

comments.text: Effort to reduce warping. I made good experience with it reducing bottom layer warping. YMMV.
comments.author: mp3lll

comments.text: Cool, i will try to use it also.
comments.author: zet23t

comments.text: Just FYI putting acrylic/glass panels on a printer like this is a bad idea.  It will lock the heat in and cause warping.  The build plate is cold and not heated for printers like these you want the hear to dissipate.
comments.author: OO_DURKE_OO

comments.text: As long as there is ventilation it shouldn't be an issue. I'm planning on doing a similar thing on my M3D. If anything the enclosure will prevent cold drafts from hitting the cooling plastic and causing uneven cooling which could lead to deformation of the model.
comments.author: OO_DURKE_OO

comments.text: Funny, I have a heating element. I also put an additional USB fan pointing into the chamber. It appears to me that warping is reduced this way. I also tested printing on a heated mirror with quite neat results.
comments.author: borzz629

comments.text:
I can confirm that having these plates on won't prevent warping.
I can also confirm that not having these plates on won't prevent warping as well.
comments.author: OO_DURKE_OO

comments.text: Sounds like you are printing at to high of a temp.  180 degrees is all that is needed for PLA and ABS is 240 but ABS can not be printed on a cold bed.  This is a PLA only printer even though they say it will do ABS.  A little hairspray on the buildtak and a heating point of 180 degrees and I have never once had anything warp.  The codes set the heat to high if you are using the M3D printing material.  They set it to 200 to 220 and it only needs to be 180 - 190 degrees F.  Use code PLA and set a custom temp.
comments.author: zet23t

comments.text: Printing at < 200°C causes the prints to separate easily into layers. I plan to add heat transfer paste and see what changes.

I made this small elegant lamp adding 5 simple sides, carved with some shapes of leaves.

Read instructions for assembly

For this small project you only need:
5 printed parts (print the .stl file 4 times)
1 Yellow Led
1 Coin Battery (3 V)
Hot Glue

When you have printed the sides, you have to put them togheter with hot glue as the sides of a cube. Then you put the LED, connected to the coin battery, under the structure. Turn off the light and see how the light passes through the holes. It will create an elegant atmosphere.

remixed_from.author: Mak-a-face
remixed_from.title: i3 Rework X-Carriage for GT2 & T2.5

description.text:
ToyREP is a tiny and inexpensive FFD 3D printer designed mostly as a technology demonstrator or child's toy. The print volume is 100x100x100mm (125x125x100mm with some upgrades) with a cold bed made of polyacrylate. Hot end is a E3D clone for 1.75 PLA or ABS filament with 0.4mm noozle. Using very cheap 28BYJ-48 stepper motors (with Bi-polar hack) in all axis and geared extruder, Arduino Mega 2560 with Ramps 1.4, DRV8825 and modular RepRap construction based on Mendel, Printerbot, Cherry, Prusa i3 and CARP Box ideas. It is designed to use 12V PSU for LED lights that should fit under bed. Power consumption is currently ca 40W when heating just hotend and 15W-20W when printing on polycarbonate bed. Or with 100x100mm PCB heatbed it will consume 75-85W when preheating and 30-45W in total when printing.

On video http://youtu.be/rhNdqjVxz4o, bridge test calibration model is printed. During this particular print it is reaching top speeds 30mm/s in X and Y axis, 0.35mm/s in Z axis and extruder can push filament up to 4mm/s. But such speeds requires higher current, so the motors are overheating and eventually the internal gear box or coils of 28BYJ-48 may got damaged.

For a reliable long term print, printer should not exceed 12.5/s in X and Y axis and 1mm/s on extruder with as low current as possible so the real speed will be close to the first layer on the video. Also usage of coolers above stepper motors is highly recommended. You can find such solution among improvements. Despite this precaution I've already burned two motors in extruder so consider this until the reason will be found.

More up to date video from October 2015 https://youtu.be/UwSxXt_PTyk of ToyREP was captured when Marvin Key Chain was made. Printer is reaching speeds 16mm/s, on X, Y and E motors are fans, DRV8825 stepper drivers are tweaked for precise current control and it is equiped with heatbed. This 11 minute long time laps is showing complete 1h41m long print and is probably most accurate example of printer's performance.

Other Print Examples

Calibration Box
Bridge Test
Treefrog
Marvin

Disclaimer

All of the information provided about ToyREP 3D Printer is provided as-is and with no warranties. Author assumes or undertakes no liability for any loss or damage suffered as a result of the use, misuse or reliance on the information and content on this project.

Warning

ToyREP, although proved working, is still experimental. The whole idea is based on 28BYJ-48 stepper motors, that are capable of driving 3D printer, but their longevity is not tested thoroughly. In two months of usage I've burned two motors. Keep that in mind when building it.

To make them last as long as possible:

  • Be very careful when disassembling the motors. Even slight shift of the PCB under the plastic cap can damage tiny wires from coils. You are doing the bipolar hack at your own risk.
  • Set the current as per the specification of the manufacturer.
  • Keep the timing belts as loose as possible. Tight belts would put side stress to the motor shaft. This is very harmful for this tiny motor.
  • Keep the working temperature of motors within manufacturers limits.

License

Please follow the CC-BY-SA terms.

  • Share freely but give credit or link to the source.
  • You can alter this design with attribution to the original. All subsequent designs have to be released under the same license.
  • Commercial use only with the consent of author.

Improvements:

  1. LED PSU mount and cover with switch for size 111x78x36mm and 129x99x38mm
  2. Frog for print area 125x125mm - uploaded to ToyREP.
  3. Bowden extruder mount - uploaded to ToyREP.
  4. ZMAX without 608ZZ bearings (to prevent wobbling) - uploaded to ToyREP.
  5. Coolers for stepper motors and different motor mount - Use them instead of X1, Y1, Z1&2 and Extruder parts uploaded here
  6. X1_M8 and X2_M8 for quicker z movement - Use them instead of X1 and X2 parts uploaded here
  7. 100x100mm PCB Heatbed by kolardan - Use it instead of polycarbonate plate
  8. 28BYJ-48 Plastic Cap - Use this cover if you want to customize the colour or you break it when disassembling steppers.
  9. Additional extruder gears for hobbed bolts with different spacing between groove and hexagonal head - uploaded to ToyREP
  10. Pulleys for T2.5 and GT2 timing belts of width up to 7mm uploaded to ToyREP files. These Rev2 parts are experimental. Use them only if (for some strange reason) you don't like original T2.5 pulley.
  11. 120x120mm PCB Heatbed by kolardan - Use it instead of polycarbonate plate
  12. 50mm Long Legs by sobo84 - print it instead of legs placed here.
  13. 3 point levelling for 100x100mm bed by timbologist.
  14. Frog for 120x120mm Aluminum Heatbed with mounting holes 112x112mm apart - uploaded to ToyREP
  15. Remixed extruder with servo for auto bed levelling BranJaq S1 by Branez
  16. Hotend Fan Duct - Use this additional cooler if you want to print PLA
  17. Geared Extruder for 3mm Fillament by TouchWARE - rest of the extruder uses the same vitamins (except for the 3mm hotend)
  18. PSU cover for 99x42mm LED PSU by Felyo - Slightly different design for enclosures higher than 38mm for what is prepared PSU2 file.
  19. NEMA 17 X and Y mounts - First viable solution prepared by moses65174 for both main axis, although it will need a bit more changes in rod and belts lengths.
  20. Servo Z probe - Plate under extruder fan to install servo designed by mwelchuk

Planned improvements (no promises :D):

  1. 40 teeth T2.5 pulleys (require also major changes in frog, carriage, X1 and X2) to achieve higher print speeds (around 25mm/s)
  2. Adjustable legs
  3. Direct drive extruder
  4. Fan mount to cool stepper drivers
  5. Mount compatible with Prusa Mendel vertical carriage
